body:
Ok, so I had a slightly different mechanism in mind. I think it would be much cleaner to just have a function like this:
```cpp
void registerInitMethod(std::string name, std::function<::thd::InitMethod::Config(std::string, int, std::string, int)> method)
```
that would register the code at run time. The users will have to insert an extra call to actually register the method before they use it, but I think that's much easier to understand than an optionally defined macro. Wdyt?
